messageBody:
Paul:

I was writing a response to your e-mail with the new font at my office.  (I pick up e-mails at work and at home.)  I did not get a chance to finish the response, and the font is not available here since it is off the server now.

The designer of a font has the right to name the font.  You might want to use a name that doesn't include "Shaw" however, since that might lead people to expect it to be a Shavian font rather than a QS one.  But that is up to you.

I think the font looks great.  I am especially pleased to see "E-at" looking right.  I know it may seem petty, but Bartok's font really annoyed me every time I used it because of that discrepancy.  You opened up the left side of the letter which should make it easier to read and distinguish, especially in smaller fonts.  In John Zuk's font, the left side of the letter was just too close to the right side.  [Jerome let us use half-letters, which was good, but there were technical problems with the font, which were never corrected.  When writing in it, at times the cursor would not appear in the place where it really was so it made it very difficult to type.  This may have been a kerning problem, but I'm really not sure.  Also, he produced this font pretty quickly, and some of the letters are not as well formed as I would like.  After Jerome, others designed "junior" fonts.  This was probably partially due to the difficulties Zuk encountered and because you don't have to enable the half letters to print correctly.]

I believe Kingsley has some or maybe all of the half letters available.  That would be nice if you could get that to work properly.  But a "junior" font where all the glyphs look correct and print properly would be excellent.  I am wondering if your font will leave spaces between adjacent letters, or would it appear to have some of the cursive quality as in handwritten senior QS?

Trying to remember my other comments...
  1. Your font seems to be missing the "wh" sound, which many of us use when we write because we pronounce the words that way. (I say seems because of the rectangular boxes, one of which could have had the "wh" glyph for all I know.)  It is simply the "w" symbol with a hook at the bottom so it should be easy to add to the font.  To me "which" and "witch" are not pronounced the same.  People who use this sound find it annoying if the font doesn't include it.  By the way, adding "wh" was one of the changes Read made in going from the Shaw alphabet to QS.
  2. When I opened the font, in several places there were rectangular boxes.  I wasn't sure if some of these may have been glyphs not displaying correctly. (I didn't have a chance to check to see if all the symbols were present.)
  3. The font should have a naming dot.  I don't remember seeing one.
  4. The font should have angled brackets to use in the place of standard parentheses.
Regarding schwa + "r."  That is the vowel + "r" combination for "bird." The vowel in "bard" should be no. 32 "A-h" + "r."

I hope this helps.  Thanks again for your work. 

Paige

Paul Tremblay wrote:


>
> No. It should not look like a "D".. The alternate letter connects the
> schwa and the "r" together as in Senior QS. I am not sure at this time
> if anyone else has used Zuk's renaming of the letters, but you are
> certainly free to do so. I liked them also. Because of the frequent
> combining of vowels with a following "r" they can be combined in one
> connected form, and you will see these in Zuk's font.
>
> I will respond to your earlier e-mail later.
>
> Paige
>

Thanks. Strangely, the character now displays correctly. I don't know
what caused the change.

I think this combination (I guess it's a ligature?) is very important.
The Earth sound has its own special symbol in the International Phonetic
Alphabet. I see bird spelled as "bard," or B-ay, U-tter, R-oe, D-ay
(or, Bob, Ado, Roar, Deed!), but this confuses me. The no confuses me
because the sound in "bird" is much more rounded than the sound in
"U-tter." To my ear, Bob, Ado, Roar, Deed could spell Bard. I keep
trying to put the schwa sound and the r together before realizing it is
the common Earth sound.

Paul
